thinking.disposable_income: Greater Eastwood has a median household income around $53,000, which is below Houston's median, indicating moderate sensitivity to transportation costs and taxes.
thinking.discretionary_consumption: Residents have limited discretionary spending power with approximately 30% of income available after essential expenses, making them somewhat price-sensitive to both transit fares and driving fees.
thinking.accessibility: The neighborhood has good access to METRO's Red Line and several bus routes, with about 15% of residents using public transit for commuting, while most households own at least one car.
thinking.decision_rationale: 1) Prioritized policies with lower transit fares ($0.75) to benefit transit-dependent residents while maintaining service quality. 2) Favored moderate tax rates (1%) to support transit without overly burdening household budgets. 3) Supported moderate driving fees ($0.50) to reduce congestion and fund transit while not excessively penalizing car-dependent trips. 4) Balanced travel time improvements with cost impacts on residents. 5) Considered the mixed-mode transportation needs of the working-class community.
